Description: Rim and body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery lekanis lid; interior:glazed black with band in added red near turn to rim; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of undetermined motif, possibly an animal's chest with added red, and bird flying to left (head, body and one wing remaining; bands of faded red along wing); incised blob rosette as filling ornament; on outside of rim narrow dilute band above black band.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The clay was analysed by M. Hughes and found to be Attic: Harbottle, G., Hughes, M. J. and Seleem, S. 'The Origin of black-figure Greek ceramics found in Naucratis (Nile Delta)', Archaeometry 47, 2005, 511-8; p.513, table 1, no.9
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 339, no. B407)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0786) (Phase 1)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
